pdhp174:1: Stupid fools live having themselves as their own foes,
pdhp174:2: committing wicked deeds, which produce bitter fruit.
pdhp175:1: How could he do that deed, which, having done, one has regret,
pdhp175:2: for which he has tears on his face, as the result follows him round.
pdhp176:1: But that deed is well done, which, having done, one has no regret,
pdhp176:2: for which he is pleased and happy, as the result follows him round.
pdhp177:1: As far as learning arises for a fool, it is only to his disadvantage,
pdhp177:2: it destroys the fool’s good quality, and it will destroy his head.
pdhp178:1: He wishes for the respect that is lacking, and status amongst the monastics,
pdhp178:2: for control in the living quarters, and worship amongst good families:
pdhp179:1: “Householders and renunciants should think this was done by me,
pdhp179:2: let none be a match for me, in all to be done and not done”,
pdhp180:1: so does the fool think, meanwhile his desires and conceit increase.
pdhp180:2: For the means to gains is one thing, the path going to Nibbāna another,
pdhp181:1: thus seeing this as it really is the disciple of the Buddha
pdhp181:2: should not delight in honours, but practise in solitude.
pdhp182:1: The fool thinks there is success, when he speaks words that are rough,
pdhp182:2: but for the one who knows, endurance is the success of the good.
pdhp183:1: Without power is the power of him whose power is the power of a fool,
pdhp183:2: reproach is not found for the powerful one, protected by Dhamma.
pdhp184:1: The fool who conceives he is a fool, is at least wise in that matter,
pdhp184:2: the fool who is proud of his wisdom, he is said to be a fool indeed.
pdhp185:1: Long is the night for one who sleeps not, long is a league for one tired,
pdhp185:2: long is the round of births and deaths for fools who know not True Dhamma.
pdhp186:1: That man who wraps up rotting fish with the best fragrant grass,
pdhp186:2: makes the fragrant grass smell rotten, and so with those who associate with fools.
pdhp187:1: That man who wraps up pinwheel in flame-tree leaves,
pdhp187:2: makes even the leaf fragrant, and so with those who associate with the wise.
pdhp188:1: If one who does no wickedness associates with those who do,
pdhp188:2: he is suspected of wickedness, and his disrepute increases.
pdhp189:1: An associate associating with others who are touched by contacts,
pdhp189:2: like a smeared arrow in a bunch, smears that which is unsmeared,
pdhp189:3: fearing being smeared the wise one will not have wicked friends.
pdhp190:1: Therefore knowing the result for oneself of the fruit container,
pdhp190:2: he should not follow the bad one, the wise one should associate with the good one.
pdhp191:1: Even if a fool attends on a wise man for his whole life long,
pdhp191:2: he does not learn Dhamma, like the spoon learns not the taste of curry.
pdhp192:1: If a perceptive man attends on a wise man even for a second,
pdhp192:2: he quickly learns Dhamma, like the tongue learns the taste of curry.
pdhp193:1: One should not despise a little wickedness thinking: it will not come to me,
pdhp193:2: through the falling of water drops the water-pot is quickly filled,
pdhp193:3: the fool, gathering bit by bit, becomes full of wickedness.
pdhp194:1: One should not despise little merit thinking: it will not come to me,
pdhp194:2: through the falling of water drops the water-pot is quickly filled,
pdhp194:3: the wise one, gathering bit by bit, becomes full of merit.
